title: Analysis and purification of innate lymphoid cells in human intestine and blood by flow cytometry
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Tissue pretreatment
Timing: 1 h 15 min
This step details how to wash the samples, remove the epithelial cell layer in adjacent tissue, and tumor.
Collect and record basic information of the tissue, e.g., weight, length.
Remove visible blood vessels and adipose tissue from the samples with forceps.
Wash each tissue with 10 mL ice-cold PBS in 10 cm cell-culture dish.
Cut the adjacent tissue into small pieces about 0.3 cm2 in area by scissors.
Put the adjacent tissue into 50 mL tube containing 20 mL Wash buffer 1 and shake at 200 rpm for 1 h at 37°C.
Cut the tumor tissue into big pieces (0.2 cm in length), wash in 50 mL tube containing 20 mL Wash buffer 2, and shake at 200 rpm for 15 min at 37°C.
After the washing step, shake normal tissues powerfully (4–5 cycles per second) for 5 min to dissociate the epithelial fraction, while shake the tube with tumor tissue gently (1 cycle per second) for 5 min.
Discard the supernatant directly and wash the tissue twice with 10 mL of PBS at about 25°C.
Tissue digestion
Timing: 1 h 30 min
This step details how to digest the adjacent gut tissue and CRC tumor into single cell suspensions.
Preparation of digestion buffer. Digestion buffer should be prepared before digestion using prewarmed complete 1640 medium.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2547_3.csv
After washing, dry the tissue with dust-free paper, and place into 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Cut tissues into very small pieces (about 1 mm in length) with scissors and transferred into 50 mL tube containing 10–20 mL digestion buffer depending on the tissue weight.
Place the tubes at a slope of about 45° to maximize contact with the liquid. Shake the tubes at 200 rpm for 60 min at 37°C.

The digested tissues are shaken vigorously with hand to dissociate thoroughly for 5 min.
Add 10 mL complete RPMI 1640 medium to slow down the digestion. In order to increase single-cell yield, use 21-gauge syringe to aspirate back and forth to mechanically dissociate the residual tissue at about 25°C.
Filter cell suspension by 100 μm cell strainer into a new canonical 50 mL tube.
Centrifuge at 700 g for 5 min at about 25°C. Discard the supernatant, and scatter the cell pellet gently with 12.5 mL complete 1640 medium.
Add 12 mL of Ficoll in a 50 mL tube and carefully lay the above cell suspension at the top of Ficoll.
Centrifuge at 1,350 g for 25 min, at about 25°C. Set the acceleration at 1 grade, and deceleration at 0 grade.
Carefully collect the medium layer into new 50 mL tubes and adjust the volume into 10 mL with ice-cold PBS.
Centrifuge at 700 g for 5 min at 4°C, and resuspend cells with 5 mL flow buffer. Pass through 70 μm cell strainer into a 15 mL tube.
Calculate the cell number by mixing 20 μL of cell suspension with 20 μL trypan blue using a hemocytomter. Record cell number and viability.
Preparation of peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs)
Timing: 1 h
This step details how to isolate PBMCs in whole blood.3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
Blood is collected with anticoagulant-treated tubes.
Dilute blood samples with equal volume of 2% FBS in PBS (1:1 dilution) at about 25°C.
Pipet up and down to mix the blood and buffer.
Add 12 mL of Ficoll to a 50 mL conical tube.
Gently transfer about 16 mL of diluted blood over the Ficoll layer.

Centrifuge the tubes at 1,350 g for 25 min, at about 25°C. Set the acceleration at 1 grade, and deceleration at 0 grade, to avoid disturbing the PBMCs interface.
Remove the diluted plasma layer at top with Pasteur pipette.
Collect the PBMCs layer, the middle white layer, into a new 15 mL conical tube.
Wash the PBMCs once with 8 mL ice-cold PBS.
Centrifuge at 700 g for 5 min at 4°C.
Carefully remove the supernatant.
Add 2 mL RBC lysing buffer and incubate the mixtures on ice for 5 min.
Add 5 mL PBS to the tube, and centrifuge at 700 g for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the PBMCs with 2 mL flow buffer and kept on ice for staining.
Antibody mix preparation
Timing: 15 min
This step details antibody mixes for staining ILCs.
Make antibody mix for staining ILCs.
Staining buffer: 20 μL of mouse serum and 50 μL of Brilliant Strain Buffer is added into 130 μL of flow buffer. Usually, 200 μL staining buffer per sample.
Block Solution: 2 μL of Fc block in 98 μL staining buffer/sample.
Antibody Mixture: 2 μL of FITC-conjugated against each lineage markers (TCR γδ, TCR αβ, CD3, CD19, CD14, CD16, CD94, CD123, CD34, CD303 and FcεRI),4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4] 2 μL of Alexa Fluor 700-CD45, 2 μL of PE-CD127, 2 μL of BV421-CD117 and 2 μL of PE-CF594-CD294 in 70 μL staining buffer/sample. This is a 2-fold antibody mixture. Final antibody dilution is 1:100.
Staining
Timing: 60 min
This step details for staining of ILCs for each sample.
Cells prepared from both tissue and blood are then washed with 1 mL of flow buffer and centrifuged at 700 g for 5 min at 4°C.
Pellets are blocked with 100 μL of Block Solution for 10 min at 4°C.

Add 100 μL of Antibody Mixture directly to the cells, vortex gently. Incubate for 30 min in dark at about 25°C.
Wash with 1 mL of flow buffer, vortex briefly and centrifuge at 700 g for 5 min at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant, resuspend the pellet with 500 μL flow buffer and filter through 40 μm nylon strainer.
Sorting
Timing: 6 h
This step details how to purify ILCs on a BD FACSAria III cell sorter.
Label collection tubes with indicated sample name, and add 1 mL of RPMI 1640 medium containing 20% FBS.
Gently vortex the tubes to rinse the tube before collection.
Set up the cell sorter with a 70 μm nozzle.
Set PMT voltages based on clear separation of positive and negative single staining.5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]
Auto-compensation is calculated with compensation beads stained with each dye. Unstained beads are used as background.
ILCs are gated on CD45+ Lineage- CD127+ after the lymphocyte, and singlets gates.
The ILCs are sorted using the 4-well purity mode.
The flow rate is set under 4 grade, and cell rates are set under 12,000 events per second.
After the sorting procedure, tubes are unloaded, and adjusted to 2 mL volume with RPMI 1640 medium containing 20% FBS.
Cells are centrifuged at 700 g for 5 min at 4°C. And supernatants are removed with pipette with about 200 μL liquid left in the tube.
The above cell suspension is transferred into a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
The cells are centrifuged at 1,500 g for 5 min at 4°C.
After centrifugation, the liquid is gently removed with a pipette.
The cell pellets might be visible under the light.

Critical: It is critical to leave about 200 μL liquid in the tube to avoid discarding the cells. The liquid volume of 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube is better than 1 mL to avoid cells sticking on the wall of tubes.
Optional: Cells could be centrifuged at 700 g for 5 min and resuspended in PBS containing Fixable Viability stain 520 (1:1000) for 10 min at 4°C before staining for dead cell removal.
Note: The digestion buffer volume is tissue weight dependent. 5 mL or less volume could be added when the tissue is less than 0.3 g. 10 mL for 0.3–0.5 g of tissue. 20 mL digestion buffer could be used when the weight is more than 0.5 g.
